Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Documentation request: update plugin Guide to JIRA High Availability and Clustering
Description: h3. Problem Definition   Current documentation regarding *Schedule a job* is not specific enough about how jobs are scheduled in cluster environment:   see page: https://developer.atlassian.com/jiradev/jira-platform/jira-data-center/plugin-guide-to-jira-high-availability-and-clustering     We need to document current status, see related JRASERVER-65632     h3. Suggested Solution   Currently docs mention:   * Jobs only run once for each scheduled run time.   * Should only be scheduled by one node in the cluster.     Please add part covering:   * There is no guaranty that only one job will be running at specific moment of time across the cluster (Singleton).   ** For example: If job configured as interval job with 1 min interval, Job will scheduled at node1 and than 1 min later at node2, so two instances of the job will be running in the cluster.   ** This should be controlled by job code itself, possibly using *Cluster Locks*.     h3. Workaround   None.

Title: Import  vs Bulk Create clarification in Archive Documentation
Description: h5. Issue Summary    If an Admin of a JIRA instance uses External System import to add issues accidentally to an archived project(or even intentionally), the issues would be created since this is considered an import rather than a creation and JIRA is designed to accept it since you do not require a project permission for the External System Import process.    h5. Clarification    Can a section be added to the [Online Archive page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver071/archiving-a-project-802592917.html] adding a disclaimer clarifying the above scenario and stating clearly that the external system import would import issues irrespective of project permission?    Also, can we have a much clearer classification and disclaimer added to the [external system import CSV page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver071/importing-data-from-csv-802592885.html] explaining that it is different from [Bulk Create Issue from CSV|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirasoftwarecloud/creating-issues-using-the-csv-importer-764478441.html] so that users are aware of the difference because it is not that clearly stated and can lead to confusion to some users.

Steps to Reproduce  # Go to the Issue Navigator.  # Switch to the Advanced mode.  # Search with JQL query: {{creator was admin}}    h3. Notes  * Creator cannot be changed in JIRA, should we even support the operators WAS, WAS IN, WAS NOT and WAS NOT IN?

Title: Migrating JIRA server documentation update for data restore
Description: Currently within the doc [Migrating JIRA applications to another server - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver073/migrating-jira-applications-to-another-server-861253107.html] has the steps of:  {quote}  3.6 Import your old data into your new JIRA applications    After you have started your new JIRA installation you should be logged in to your JIRA application, and ready to import the data from your old instance into the new instance. You will need the backup file of data from your old JIRA that you created earlier in these instructions ( above).    To import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA:    # Log in as a user with the 'JIRA System Administrators' global permission.  # Select Administration > System > Import & Export > Restore System (tab) to open the 'Restore JIRA data from Backup' page.  # In the File name field, specify the XML backup file you created previously during the export process (above). That zipped file should contain two xml files: activeobjects.xml and entities.xml. Both of these files must be included in the zipped file for the import process to work.  # Restore the attachments directory that you backed up previously, into the attachments directory of your new JIRA. (See Restoring data.)      (info) Avoid passing through a proxy when performing an XML restore, especially if your JIRA instance is very large. Using a proxy may cause timeout errors.   {quote}    But this is not actually what happens here.  If you follow all these step up to this point, when you start JIRA, you won't actually be logged into JIRA at all (how could you, the database is totally empty at this point).  When you start JIRA with an empty data as was the steps of this doc, you start JIRA in the initial setup wizard.  From here you can actually click the link for 'import existing data' and then simply select the XML backup here to restore.    That part is a minor difference but I would like to clarify that first.   In order to follow the steps in the current guide, you would need to create a new admin account and finish the initial setup wizard of JIRA before you can gain access to the System -> Restore data option.  Which is just misleading.    Also there is a bigger problem with following these steps if you are also upgrading JIRA at this time.  If you follow these current steps, and JIRA is upgraded to a new version where the naming convention of attachments has changed (I know it has happened between 6.4 and 7.0, and again in 7.2), then following these steps will result in your previous attachments in JIRA being inaccessible to you in the new instance because the database references for these files in the {{fileattachments}} table get updated with the new naming convention when the XML import happens, but the actual flat files themselves are not in place in order for JIRA to rename them yet.  Leaving the customer with broken attachments that are actually a pain to fix and additional support cases waiting to happen.      Instead I would recommend these steps:      {panel:borderStyle=dashed| borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}    3.6 Import your old data into your new JIRA applications    After you have started your new JIRA installation you will notice that JIRA will launch its initial setup wizard.   This happens anytime JIRA starts with an empty database.  From here you can import your backup file in order to populate your XML backup data into your new empty database. You will need the backup file of data from your old JIRA that you created earlier in these instructions ( above).    To import your old JIRA data into your new JIRA:    # Restore the attachments directory that you backed up previously, into the attachments directory of your new JIRA. (See Restoring data.)  # Start JIRA  # In the setup wizard select the option for 'Import existing data'  # In the File name field, specify the XML backup file you created previously during the export process (above). That zipped file should contain two xml files: activeobjects.xml and entities.xml. Both of these files must be included in the zipped file for the import process to work.      (info) Avoid passing through a proxy when performing an XML restore, especially if your JIRA instance is very large. Using a proxy may cause timeout errors.    {panel}    Steps 5 and 6 on that doc should be unchanged.

Problem Definition    The JIRA Cloud Document: [Import and export data |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html]   for step 1 refers to JIRA applications [Importing issues |https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/importing-issues-776636788.html] This document details at Point 2 step 1:  {quote}2. (For backup files larger than 4GB, refer to [Uploading Large files to WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloudkb/uploading-large-files-to-webdav-747834468.html])  {quote}  The first link: [using WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/upload-data-via-webdav-744721622.html] is a reciprocal link back to document 1 with no additional information    The Second Link [Uploading Large files to WebDAV |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloudkb/uploading-large-files-to-webdav-747834468.html] Notes the Deprication of the webdav with:  {quote}(!) For updated import information, please refer to [Import and export data |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html].  {quote}  The link provided [Import and export data |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/import-and-export-data-744721621.html] is also a link back to the first document with no additional information on the new process for uploading data for a Import.  h3. Suggested Solution    The new process needs to be detailed in the import documentation directly.    Since of the Depreciation of the WebDav the new process has been added in the Cloud instance directly on the *Second Step* of the *JIRA Import Wizard* So the only way to notified of the new process is to initiate the process before reading the documentation pages as you must start the import to reveal these details:  {quote}  h2.Before you begin  # Back up your JIRA Cloud site data using Backup Manager   # Prepare an export of your other JIRA Cloud or Server instance.   # If you want to include attachments, avatars, or logos in this import, create compressed copies of the following:   * <JIRA_HOME>/data/attachments directory (with attachments as the top-level directory, or project keys within attachments as the top-level directory).   * <JIRA_HOME>/data/avatars directory (with avatars as the top-level directory)   * <JIRA_HOME>/logos directory (with logos as the top-level directory)  {quote}  !Screen Shot 2017-02-06 at 4.41.01 PM.png|thumbnail!    Between step 2 and 3 the JIRA Import File only file is uploaded from local file system to the webdav, and there is still no indication of were in the process attachments, avatars, or logos files are to be uploaded. Step 3 Notes:  {quote}  Before the import is started, the JIRA export and optional archives must be uploaded to your Atlassian Cloud instance using WebDAV. For instructions on connecting to your WebDAV directory, [see this documentation | http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Cloud/Uploading+Data+via+WebDAV]. Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-63730].   {panel}  h2. Definition    As per this [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracoreserver072/search-syntax-for-text-fields-829092675.html], it should be possible to search in the issue navigator using special characters.  {quote}    JIRA supports the ability to search issues for special characters by escaping them in your query syntax. The current list of such characters is:    {quote}    However, it is not working as expected. Searching like summary !~ *\\] fails with error The text query '*\]' for field 'summary' is not valid: the '*' and '?' are not allowed as first character in wildcard query and summary !~ \\] returns all the issues.     I came across to this [bug report|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-40790] which was eventually not closed as *Answered*.   {quote}  To do this we use Lucene's ClassicTokenizer which:  # Splits words at punctuation characters, removing punctuation. However, a dot that's not followed by whitespace is considered part of a token.  # Splits words at hyphens, unless there's a number in the token, in which case the whole token is interpreted as a product number and is not split.  # Recognizes email addresses and internet hostnames as one token.    As a result the [ and ] characters are neither added to the index or retained in the phrase query.  {quote}    There were comments about documentation update to avoid confusion but there was no follow up whether a ticket has been created for that or not. So here it is.

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Difference between Day & Time search is not explained in any JQL documentation
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-62871].   {panel}  Problem Definition   For example, searching for {{-1d}} vs {{-24h}} in query gives completely different results. However this is not highlighted or explained in our documentation.   * When specifying {{-1d}}, it will start calculating on the day when you executed it (which includes today itself if you execute the query now). It does not take into account the amount of time relative to the time you had executed it, ie 24 hours from the time you executed the JQL.   * When specifying {{-24h}}, it will start calculating from the hour when you executed it, ie 24 hours from the time you executed the JQL.    Let's assume there is an issue that was transitioned to Closed yesterday 3PM, and the query is executed 1PM today:   * {{status changed to Closed after -1d}} will not return the result but {{status changed to Closed after -2d}} will   * {{status changed to Closed after -24h}} will return the result    Suggested Solution   Include a section in Advanced JQL Search documentation to explain the differences.

Title: Update documentation for JIRA 6.4 Supported Platforms to mention more recent jTDS drivers
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-62394].   {panel}  [JIRA 6.4 Supported Platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira064/supported-platforms-720411857.html] indicates that for MS SQL the JTDS driver version 1.2.4 is supported.    However, more recent versions are available and offer substantial benefits. From the jTDS release notes for 1.3.0:  {quote}  The new versions are a quite huge update, also fixing a number of critical bugs and improving the performance, so we'd highly encourage you to upgrade.    Version 1.3.0 is the first Java 7 compatible version of the driver and, beside the fix for bug #672, improves performance compared to version 1.2.7. The future development will be focused on the 1.3.x line of the driver, so further enhancements and bug fixes will not necessarily become available it the Java 1.3 compatible jTDS 1.2.x. You should only stick to jTDS 1.2 if you require to use a Java version prior to Java 7.  {quote}

As of 5.7.6, creation of a foreign key constraint requires the REFERENCES privilege for the parent table. Problem Definition    Migration from JIRA Server to Cloud has currently this bug:  https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-60588    Basically, if the user migrate from JIRA Server to Cloud and the System timezone is different, this will cause a serious problem where dates are actually changed on migration.    This can be prevented is the user, for example, creates a Cloud instance in the same timezone as the Server. However, this can only be prevented, as we don't have a good and safe way to fix this problem after the migration is done.    Letting the customers know in advance about this problem may prevent many users with the same problem.    h3. Suggested Solution  Add a warning to [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/migrating-from-jira-server-to-jira-cloud-779160826.html] warning the customer to this bug and asking them to make sure the timezones match.    Suggested message:  {quote}  JIRA Server to Cloud migration is current affected by the JRA-60588 bug, which may incorrectly migrate some dates.. To prevent this problem, please make sure to migrate to a JIRA Cloud using the same timezone as the source JIRA Server.  {quote}

Ensure your database is configured to use the same character encoding as JIRA. The recommended encoding is AL32UTF8 (the Oracle equivalent of Unicode UTF-8).    Meanwhile JIRA does the health-check and uses *BINARY* Collation, see   [Health Check: Database Collation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Health+Check%3A+Database+Collation], section _Supported Collations_    This Collation vs Character encoding is confusing. Please align docs and current JIRA recommendation.   Oracle character encoding: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/NLSPG/ch2charset.htm#NLSPG171  Oracle Collation: http://docs.oracle.com/database/121/NLSPG/ch5lingsort.htm#NLSPG1017

[See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-60488].   {panel}  The only reference for Custom Field contexts in our official documentation is:  {quote}  h3. Adding a new context    Adding a new context allows you to configure a custom field differently for different combinations of issue types and projects.    *To add a new context:*  # Navigate to the Custom Fields page, locate the desired custom field and choose cog icon > Configure.  # Click the Add new context link. The 'Add configuration scheme context' page will be displayed (see below).  #* Under 'Add configuration scheme context', enter a 'Label' and 'Description' for your new context — these are used for administrative purposes only and will not be shown to your end-users.  #* Under 'Choose applicable issue types', select the issue type(s) to which you want this Default Value and Options to apply. Although the application functions properly with Java 7, but there are a large number of cases - especially when it comes to medium to large instances - when the performance on Java 7 is significantly worse than it is on Java 8, not to talk about the same instance running on earlier versions of JIRA.    h4. Proposed solution  We already have a [knowledge base article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Java+8+improves+JIRA+application+performance+dramatically] that describes the performance gain on Java 8, but customers who upgrade or install JIRA will not necessarily browse through the KB space.     We should mention the significant performance impact when using Java 7 in both the supported platforms documentation and the related upgrade documentation to clarify the situation and avoid post-mortem suggestions for customers being affected by this issue.    We should probably also evaluate removing Java 7 as supported platform for these versions, given the number of performance related issues we see.    h5. References  - [*Java 8 improves JIRA application performance dramatically*|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Java+8+improves+JIRA+application+performance+dramatically]  - [JIRA 6.3.x supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira063/supported-platforms-683541780.html]  - [JIRA 6.4.x supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/supported-platforms-207488170.html]  - [JIRA 6.3 upgrade notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/jira-6-3-upgrade-notes-596771073.html]  - [JIRA 6.4 upgrade notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/jira-6-4-upgrade-notes-687014821.html]  - [Upgrading JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/upgrading-jira-185729508.html]

Title: Document how Add-on license is checked when there are multiple Applications with different User-tiers
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-59991].   {panel}  h4. +Summary+  In JIRA 7, it's possible that each Application uses a different User-tier for its license. It seems that an add-on license is always checked against the Application with the higher/highest User-tier.    h4. +Scenario+  # Install JIRA Software 7  # Use JIRA Software 10-user license  # Use JIRA Core 25-user license  # Install an add-on and use a 10-user license for it    The add-on can be configured to be used by only those users who have JIRA Software access, however this doesn't matter as the add-on license is checked against JIRA Core license, which makes it *incompatible*.    (i) The same behavior is observed when JIRA Software uses 25-user license and JIRA Core uses 10-user license.    h4. +Suggestion+  Since this seems to be the way UPM has always checked for add-on licenses, it should be well documented somewhere. This is necessary in JIRA 7, where each application can use a different user-tier.    (!) Another suggestion may be to make it possible for an add-on to only work with one specific application, against which its license is checked.

[See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-59713].   {panel}  The documentation for JIRA Software 7.0's Project Import tool, at [https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver070/restoring-a-project-from-backup-749383456.html], lacks clarity when it comes to importing Agile-style JIRA projects. The Project Import documentation states:    {color:#14892c}If you wish to retain a customized workflow from your backup, you will need to create a new workflow in your target JIRA instance and manually edit the new workflow (e.g. create steps and transitions) to reflect your old workflow   . . . Or must the new empty projects be created as Agile projects from the start (via an Agile-enabled project template)?    C) I often assign the same workflow to multiple non-Aglie projects.  Is it possible for Agile projects to have shared workflows?  Or must each Agile project have a distinct workflow?    D) Please provide some sample SQL queries that could be used to re-establish Boards and other Agile data that the JIRA Software 7.0 Import Tool currently skips.  So far, the best procedure I have found is at [https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/18448856/how-to-import-jira-agile-sprint-data-project-by-project], but there is no way for me to know whether these steps are correct and complete.

Problem Definition  * The documentation  https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/connecting-jira-to-postgresql-185729433.html cover a minimal amount of basic security configuration so that the database user ID which JIRA uses to connect to the database is properly configured. Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Clarify the meaning of snapshot in the -backing up data- documentation
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-59424].   {panel}  As per costumer feedback:  {quote}  It may be better to exclude the whole /jira-home/caches/ directory all together, as it looks like this is just temporary content as well as the indexes. There is also the tmp folder, which looks to be the same kind of thing. I'd guess those two locations are the most likely to be modified during a copy.    I've tried copying the HOME folder without either of those two directories (using exclude commands in rsync) and Jira actually starts up fine without them. It re-creates them when it first runs and starts to fill them with content again. The index page says that the index is missing and that it should be restored and re-built; re-creating it only took 6 minutes or our test system.    I think it would be very good to update the documentation in light of all this. Right now, it says create a snapshot of the data directory (including all files and subdirectories), then back up the snapshot:    https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/backing-up-data-185729581.html    I think it would be better and clearer to say:    The recommended method of backing up the data directory is to copy it to another location while excluding both the /jira-data/caches/ and /jira-data/tmp folders, and then to archive the copied folder (using zip, tar.gz, etc). This is because the content in those two folders is frequently modified, which may cause the copy to fail, and because Jira will simply re-create these folders and their content if they are missing.    NOTE: the Jira index is stored inside the caches directory, so will be lost using this method. You can enable restorable index in the system options to create backups of the index, which you can then restore later. Alternatively, if time is available, you can re-create the index from scratch after you have restored Jira.    Here is an example rsync command for the copy:    rsync -avh --delete --exclude 'caches' --exclude 'tmp' --stats --progress /jira-data/ /jira-rsync/        That would definately have helped me when I was configuring the backup.  {quote}

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Documentation for JIRA Data Center upgrade
Description: We need docs for upgrading JIRA Data Center.     Could use https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/upgrading-confluence-data-center-1507377.html as a template, seems like they are fairly similar.    h5. Upgrade steps.   You will need to shutdown all the nodes before upgrading, and then upgrade each node one-by-one.    We would recommend to do the following steps:  # Shutdown all nodes  # Do full back-up  #* JIRA DB  #* Shared folder   #* <JIRA_Install> binaries   #* <JIRA_HOME> at each node  # Delete old plugin cache (<JIRA_HOME>/plugins/) at each node   # Upgrade node 1 (uncompressing the tar file to a new directory)  # Start up node 1 (this will upgrade the DB), update all plugins to their supportive version for new JIRA version (see [Upgrade+Guide+for+JIRA+7.2|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Upgrade+Guide+for+JIRA+7.2] for example) and perform Full reindex.  # Copy the JIRA installation directory from node1 to node2 (keep in mind you will need to change the JIRA_HOME for node2)  # Delete the lucene index on node2 in the JIRA_HOME directory   # Start up _node2_  # Wait for _node2_ to start-up and copy index from _node1_  # Repeat for other nodes

[JIRA REST API Tutorials|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Tutorials] mention the use of cookie based authentication but there are no examples or guides on it. Only basic authentication and Oauth.    It would be useful to have a Tutorial on using HTTP Cookies so customers start using that since the very beginning and don't run into performance problems that stop their daily activities.

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Ambiguous swapGroup parameter in Delete Group REST API
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-44332].   {panel}  According to REST API documentation for Delete Group, you can pass a swapGroup query param (which is optional) which is a group to transfer visibility restrictions of the group that is being deleted.     One could expect that passing the param would result in replacing deleted group with swapped group in all schemes (permission, notification, issue security) but also comments and worklogs where you restricted visibility. Which is not true. The group is swapped only for comments and worklogs. Someone decided that visibility restrictions stands only for these two entities. However you do restrict visibility of an issue by setting its security level, don't you?    Probably we can't change behaviour of the resource (it's part of API) and underlying GroupService, but we can at least document it better, as is the GroupService#deleteGroup documented, so it's clear what will get swapped.    We'd also consider retiring GroupService#deleteGroup and DELETE /group?swapGroup behaviour in favour of swapping groups in comments and worklogs but also all schemes, which will make it consistent with RoleService and DELETE /role implementation, which (will) swap role in comments, worklogs, and schemes.

Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-41314].   {panel}  In the Rapid Upgrade Method documentation (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Upgrading+JIRA+Using+a+Rapid+Upgrade+Method), the following steps are provided to guide customers on how to migrate their customisations:  {quote}  iv. Start your new (upgraded) JIRA installation.  (!) If you noted any files that contain customizations which must be migrated manually to your upgraded JIRA installation (above), then:  1. Stop the upgraded JIRA installation.  2. Migrate the customizations from these files into the upgraded JIRA Installation Directory.  3. Restart the upgraded JIRA installation.  {quote}    This is not clear enough, since the customisations must be manually entered in the new files once the installation is completed. Copying the files from the old installation might cause many problems, as there might be changes in the default files from the old to the new version which won't be carried over.    This procedure is actually better explained in our other document for the [manual upgrade method|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Upgrading+JIRA+Manually#UpgradingJIRAManually-4.Postupgradechecksandtasks]:  {quote}  3.4 Migrate your existing JIRA configurations over to your new JIRA installation  If you have modified properties in configuration files of your existing JIRA installation, make the same modifications in your new JIRA installation. However, because the properties in the configuration files may have changed between versions, you cannot simply copy the configuration files from your existing installation and replace the equivalent files in the new installation.    For each file you have modified in your existing JIRA installation, you need to *manually edit each equivalent file in your new JIRA installation and re-apply your modifications.* If a file is not present in your new JIRA installation (for example, osuser.xml in recent JIRA versions), then simply copy that file over to your new JIRA installation.  {quote}

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: JIRA showing Russia/Moscow timezone as +4 instead of +3
Description: The current timezone in Moscow is GMT +3 hours, but JIRA still shows it as +4 [^Moscow.jpg]. This is causing time displays to be off for users with their default timezones set to Moscow +4.     Additionally, updating the JVM's timezone data using the tzupdater tool doesn't seem to help. It fixes the display issue where Moscow will now show +3, but all the dates and times displayed in JIRA are still ahead by 1 hour.     *Workaround*   *==========*  # Change the timezone settings (profile or General Configuration) to use *GMT OFFSET +03:00* OR  # Update joda-time in {{atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/lib}} to last version (2.5). Download the library from [here|https://github.com/JodaOrg/joda-time/releases]. Next, update JAVA's timezone data using the tzupdater tool: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/tzupdater-readme-136440.html

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Update Mail Handler Documentation
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-38662].   {panel}  After did some further investigation in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-193355 support request, it seem  our [Create a new issue or add a comment to an existing issue|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+Issues+and+Comments+from+Email#CreatingIssuesandCommentsfromEmail-Createanewissueoraddacommenttoanexistingissue] article information is not complete.    Perhaps, we can include the following details:    {quote}  An email is classified as 'bulk' if any of the following is true:  * The first 'Precedence' header in the message is 'bulk'  * The message is a multipart/report message and the content type contains 'report-type=delivery-status'  * The message is not a multipart/report message and the Return-Path is <>  * The message contains the header Auto-Submitted with a value different than no    If an email is 'bulk', there are three possible actions:  * The mail is ignored, the debug log should have the line Ignoring email with bulk delivery type, adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.  * The mail is forwarded, the debug log should have the line Forwarding email with bulk delivery type, adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.  * The mail is deleted, the debug log should have the line Deleting email with bulk delivery type, adds the log line 'Rejecting message due to failed bulk check.' and the issue/comment *is not* created.    If the email is 'bulk' but the MailHandler does not have a valid config for 'bulk=', it will be processed as any regular (i.e. non bulk) mail. Note: this assumption needs to be tested, the MailHandler might set a default 'bulk' value)   {quote}    We think the doc need to add more information, as in it does not include the multipart/report cases, it does not mention that *not* configuring bulk will include those emails in the regular process (see note above) and does not makes it clear enough that configuring 'bulk' means those bulk emails will not create issues/comments.

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: When editing an existing Crowd directory to change the application password, the application password value is reset to the old value after clicking Test Settings
Description: If you change the application password in Crowd, then when you go to edit this password in JIRA, you are forced to click Test Settings before you can Save and Test. After clicking Test Settings, the value of the password is then reset in the form to the previous value, so if you immediately click Save and Test after Test Settings, the same password will be saved again.    h4. Steps to Reproduce    # Set up an application in Crowd  # Connect JIRA to that application and check it's synchronising successfully  # Change the application password for that application in Crowd  # Disable and re-enable the directory in JIRA to immediately invalidate the session to Crowd  # Force a sync and watch it fail  # Edit the directory  # Enter the new password and click Test Settings  # After the test succeeds, click Save and Test  # Observe that the sync still fails  # Observe that the password value stored in cwd_directory_attribute table is still holding the old password    h4. Expected Results    The value should be held after clicking Test Settings, so that then clicking Save and Test will work correctly.    h4. Actual Results    The value is lost, so the new password doesn't get saved    h4. Workaround    After clicking Test Settings, enter the new password again into the form before clicking Save and Test    h4. Workaround for Delegated LDAP Connector  (!) Do not click the 'Test Settings' button  - Open console in the browsers developer tools and run the following commands    - That will allow you to click the 'Save and Test' button, with first clicking 'Test Settings'

Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Permit move operation to retain inactive user as assignee/reporter of the issue
Description: Raised this improvement on behalf of customer    {quote}During a bulk move operation, I discovered that it is only possible to bulk move issues if I set the inactive accounts as active, otherwise either the assignee or reporter fields are prompted for.    I suspect this behavior is arising from the fact that a 'move' requires a 'create' to occur in the destination project, which in turn requires all users to be active, since it is not permitted to manually edit an issue's assignee or reporter to an inactive user.    However, in this particular use-case, it would be very desirable to be able to preserve the reporter and assignee even if the user account is inactive.  {quote}    The ideal solution would be to permit a move operation to retain inactive users as either assignees or reporters.    h4. Workaround  # Temporarily activate the user  # Perform the bulk operation  # Deactivate the user    This would help retain the history of the issue correctly.

Title: JIRA REST does not return errors on transitioning an issue
Description: The outcome of the transition is ignored, and all we get back is an empty 204 response. Name: Atlassian Jira Server
Title: Wording for sharing Filters and Dashboards with Everyone is misleading
Description: {panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}   *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-29503].   {panel}  When users share filters or Dashboards with 'Everyone' the following message is displayed:  Sharing with everyone will make this visible to users who are not logged in.    But this leads them to believe that only jira-users not logged will be able to view and not every person that manages to find the 'Manage Filters' or 'Manage Dashboards' link.    Also, on the 'Manage Filters' or 'Manage Dashboards' screen they are displayed as 'Shared with all users' which strengthens the belief that it is only shared with internal users.    It would be better to change this labels to 'Share with world' to enforce that everyone will have access to the filters.
